item.title: Hell and Back Again clip
item.dc:creator: Danfung Dennis
item.description:
facebook.com/​HellandBackAgainTheMovie

What does it mean to lead men in war? What does it mean to come home? Hell and Back Again is a cinematically revolutionary film that asks and answers these questions with a power and intimacy no previous film about the conflict in Afghanistan has been able to achieve.

In this groundbreaking work of cinema, two overlapping narratives are brilliantly intercut – the life of a Marine at war on the front, and the life the same Marine in recovery, at home – creating both a dreamlike quality and a strikingly realistic depiction of how Marines experience this war.

Following Sergeant Nathan Harris of Echo Company, 2nd Battalion, 8th Marine Regiment, during a major assault on a Taliban stronghold, and his painful return home after a severe injury, the two stories communicate both the extraordinary drama of war and the no less shocking experience of returning home, as a whole generation of Marines struggle to find an identity in a country that prefers to be indifferent.

Cast: Danfung Dennis

item.title: Two Men
item.dc:creator: Dominic Allen
item.description:
Multi award winning Australian short film, Two Men, directed by Dominic Allen and shot in the Kimberly town of Fitzroy Crossing by Joel Betts, features a robust and dynamic cast of indigenous Australian non actors. Based on Kafka's short story, Two Men Running, Allen's short film has been screened in a swathe of international film festivals including New York, Prague, London, Melbourne and Sydney and in 2009 was a Dendy Australian Short Film of the Year finalist.

The film was instrumental in supporting director Dominic Allen's Emerging Australian Filmmaker Award at the Melbourne International Film Festival and the 2009 Inside Film Rising Talent Award.

2009 MIFF Jury member Deb Verhoeven remarked "Two Men proves that the simplest scenario can provide the perfect premise for conveying the most profound insights. But (Allen's) key achievement is to understand that even the largest ideas are best told with brevity and the most serious with humour."

Two Men was made with the support of Yiriman, a community initiated and community driven project supported by the Kimberley Aboriginal Law and Culture Centre which aims to build stories, strength and resilience in the Kimberley's youth.

Two Men is distributed by Flickerfest.

Cast: Dominic Allen, Timothy Melville

media:content.media:title: Two Men
media:content.media:category: Two Men, Australia, Broome, Kafka, Short, Short Film, Aboriginal, Indigenous, MIFF, SFF, Dendy, Fitzroy Crossing.

item.title: BOGOTÁ -CÓRDOBA
item.dc:creator: Diego Piñeros Garcia
item.description:
Bogotá - Córdoba nace como resultado de una residencia artística realizada entre los meses de septiembre y octubre de 2010 en la ciudad de Córdoba, Argentina, gracias a un premio estimulo otorgado por la Alcaldía Mayor de Santa fe de Bogotá, por medio de la fundación Gilberto Alzate Avendaño. En convenio con Casa 13 de la ciudad de Córdoba. Y que tenía como fin principal realizar un paralelo en el sentir y palpitar de cada ciudad por medio de la producción “artística” audiovisual más reciente.
Esta muestra se ha presentado en Casa 13 (Córdoba-Argentina), La Oficina Proyectista (Buenos Aires-Argentina) Taller ALCO dirigido por Patricio Larrambebere (Buenos Aires-Argentina) y Residencia Artística Casa Banasta (en el marco del XI Festival de cine de Santa fe de Antioquia - Colombia).


Córdoba.
Silvana Mancini, Mariángel Magaquián, Guillermina Bustos, Matías Corrias, Juan Paz, Silvana Staudinger, Marcos Oviedo, Guadalupe Guerrero, Valentina Cuello, Laura Colombo y Pamela de la Vega.

Bogotá:
Mariana Rojas, Diego Gómez, Alejandra Rincón, Colectivo Zunga (Ana María Villate, Lorena Morris, Karla Moreno, Natalia Ávila), Juan Pablo Rodríguez, Felipe Uribe, Paola Michaels, Carlos Montaña, María Angélica Madero, Raquel Solórzano y Diego Piñeros García.

Cast: Diego Piñeros Garcia

media:content.media:title: BOGOTÁ -CÓRDOBA
media:content.media:category: diego piñeros garcia

item.title: Santiniketan {india Vol.01}
item.dc:creator: ROFILMS
item.description:
A bit off the beaten path this time. Santiniketan, West Bengal State, India. A town made famous by India’s first Nobel Laureate, Rabindranath Tagore who founded the “Visva Bharati University” in 1921. It is Approximately 220 km. by road (about 4 hours) from Kolkata (formerly known as Calcutta).

The town is a fairly peaceful place when compared to major Indian cities. Not much to see in terms of infrastructures or monuments - which means not many tourists. But Santiniketan is a charming place. Most of the people are exceptionally adorable. Also if you like fine art and literature, you’re in for a treat because the university has one of best art schools in India. Several foreign students from across the globe can be found continuing their MFA in this prestigious school.

▽▲▽▲▽▲▽▲▽▲▽▲▽▲▽▲▽

An ultra fun and upbeat video this time with loads of randomness. Most of the texts that appear are not meant to be read seriously - just decorations to get that sort of random fun feel.

The footages were taken on my latest work trip to India, researching for a biographical feature film about a Thai artist who studied at the university back in the 1940's. I actually was there back in 2005 as a goodwill representative from my home university in Japan. Didn't expect in a million years that I'll be back there again. lol

Anyways, enjoy ; )

▽▲▽▲▽▲▽▲▽▲▽▲▽▲▽▲▽

Music: "Mondo Wack"
by Juanitos

Filmed & Edited by:
Roj Jayaphorn

Tools:
▲ 7D + Tamron 18 -270mm, Nikor 50mm f1.2 & 85mm f1.4
△ FCP & AfterEffects


September, 2010
a roFilms Travel {india Vol.01}
vimeo.com/​channels/​rotravel

Cast: ROFILMS

media:content.media:title: Santiniketan {india Vol.01}
media:content.media:category: travel, india, santiniketan, 7D

item.title: My 70s Life on Film
item.dc:creator: Rick Macomber
item.description:
This is a documentation of my life in the crazy early seventies, which includes silent film footage I shot with my Dad's home movie camera at The Summer Jam Concert at Watkins Glen, NY with The Band, The Allman Brothers and The Grateful Dead. With over 600,00 drugged out hippies dancing in the mud, more people than Woodstock had amassed (albeit without the media coverage) it was for the most part a peaceful event. Some of the kids in this film are deceased. Drug overdoses, murder or simply age are among the causes of death. R.I.P. my old friends.

Other footage in this montage was filmed during my "motorcycle phase" and then during my one year cross country trek with my two friends Kevin and Greg, and our puppies "Ernie" the old english sheep dog and "Montana" my golden retriever. We all got along just peachy in my green VW micro bus. Well... that is until the trip was coming to a close... when things started to get a bit "dicey" aboard the ship. Oh well. Guess all good things must come to an end : )

Cast: Rick Macomber

media:content.media:title: My 70s Life on Film
media:content.media:category: seventies, 70s, watkins glen, summer jam, allman brothers, grateful dead, key west, sand dunes monument, vw bus, the band
